The Gentlemen marks Guy Ritchie’s return to the genre that defined his early career: the sharply constructed British crime caper. With a polished ensemble cast led by Matthew McConaughey, the film blends dark comedy, layered negotiation, and violent power plays into a story that is less about drugs and crime than about hierarchy, loyalty, and reputation in a world that treats business and brutality as inseparable.

The film follows Mickey Pearson, an American-born cannabis kingpin in England who attempts to sell his highly profitable empire and retire cleanly. What should be a controlled exit instead becomes a chain reaction of manipulation, blackmail, double-crosses, and escalating violence triggered by those eager to exploit the power vacuum his departure might create. The narrative is framed through a meta-storytelling device: a tabloid journalist (Hugh Grant) recounts events to Pearson’s lieutenant (Charlie Hunnam), presenting the plot as both truth and screenplay pitch. This structure allows for unreliable narration, shifting perspectives, and intentional withholding of information until the final act.

McConaughey plays Pearson with quiet menace rather than theatrical aggression. His character operates on the belief that class and control are stronger weapons than intimidation, a philosophy repeatedly tested. Charlie Hunnam’s performance as Raymond, Pearson’s loyal fixer, is understated but pivotal; he embodies the calm professionalism that holds the empire together.

Hugh Grant is the film’s standout. Against type, he plays Fletcher as a sleazy, opportunistic storyteller whose charm and desperation make him both entertaining and unpredictable. Colin Farrell offers the film’s moral contrast: a criminal who still possesses principles, making him one of the few characters whose loyalty isn’t transactional.

Henry Golding’s Dry Eye represents the new criminal generation, aggressive, impatient, and lacking the sophistication of those who built the industry before him. The contrast between “old-world” and “new-money” crime gives the film its thematic backbone.

At its core, The Gentlemen isn’t about drugs, it’s about the currency of respect. Every conflict stems from underestimating the wrong man or failing to understand the rules of the power structure. The film also critiques class dynamics: Pearson’s business thrives not in alleyways but beneath aristocratic estates, protected by the very class that pretends to be above criminality.

Ritchie’s direction is tighter and more mature than some of his earlier work. The film retains his signature rhythms, fast dialogue, abrupt violence, nonlinear reveals, but avoids the visual excess of his mid-career projects. Instead, the film depends on timing, verbal sparring, and plot architecture rather than spectacle.

It was nice seeing Matthew McConney play this character. It’s very different than what he usually does and a hard character to play but he did an amazing job. The Gentlemen is one of Ritchie’s most controlled and satisfying crime films since Snatch. It succeeds through sharp writing, committed performances, and a narrative that rewards attention rather than pandering for it. It’s not groundbreaking, but it is expertly executed, and it reminds audiences why the “British gangster film” became a genre in the first place.

Oops, that one is from 2024 and this one, with Mc.Conaughy, from 2019. So actually the one I saw later was released earlier... never mind, my opinion is almost the same on both. The one with Theo James is actually better in buildup and funnier imo, except for the needlessly and illogic violent ending.

In any case, Guy, come off your obsession with the word 'Gentlemen' - 3rd movie where it features !

It's amazing when you don't expect much from a movie, but you go in just for the cast and end up with something phenomenal. The storytelling in this film is very enjoyable and easygoing, perfect for watching on a Sunday after lunch without any expectations. The entire cast is good, and the director and screenwriter know what they're doing, delivering quality and passion in just the right measure.

Impeccably cast, intense and filled with Guy Ritchie's snappy style, The Gentlemen is a fun and fast-paced picture that also has some great dialogue to it, but it is hard to follow on a story level and a lot of scenes doesn't mesh well together. I also didn't find myself invested in a lot of the characters, even though the actors portrayed them wonderfully
Non-stop Guy Ritchie kinda fun. Hugh Grant is a hoot.
This movie is so badass and funny. Colin Farrell absolutely kills it as The Coach. This is one of Guy Ritchie’s best movies, right next to Snatch and Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

I have a weakness for crime comedies, so unsurprisingly, The Gentleman is right up my alley. It's a relatively by-the-book crime story if you strip away the paint, but not every story has to reinvent the wheel, and the movie earns a lot of points for style. The narrative framing works in the film's favor, the screenplay is witty, and the actors have a lot of fun with it - Hugh Grant and Colin Farell are standouts.
Absolutely wonderful. The writing is very enjoyable. There were no loose ends, everything came together and the little details were not missed
Really good acting especially by Colin Farrell. Awesome script and a freaking well made film
Fun movie with a great cast.
My god ... it's too good and McConaughey cooked it. Overall one of the best I have ever seen. Love it

All Time Classic. This is Guy Ritchie returning to his roots and soaring. Masterfully crafted crime thriller the entire way. It's got a meta factor to it that adds to the already strong writing, dialouge, and snappy polish sheen the whole thing has from start to finish. Filled with twists and turns the entire way. There isn't any deep message to this or commentary. It's just a fun awesome crime flick with that Guy Ritchie touch. I think I personally like this most of all because it doesn't feel like it's influenced as much by Pulp Fiction. Everyone should gvie this a try once.
Well written, great acting and a peculiar way to present us the story. Definitely an interesting movie to watch. the double crossing is strong with this one. Recommended.

Guy Ritchie perfects his unique blend of British grit and wit in this stylish crime drama. With an ensemble cast in their prime and a compelling love letter of a script, The Gentlemen submerges you into the powerful underground business of weed distribution and the colorful characters that it produces. This is Guy Ritchie at his best and unfortunately has yet to be topped with his more recent additions. The Gentlemen churns out raw and visceral emotions that build into a most satisfying final act that leaves you wanting more. The only thing keeping this being a full 5-star film is the British rapper segments.
